questions.question: What technique extends physical memory using disk space?
questions.explanation: Virtual memory allows processes to use more memory than physically available by storing less-used pages on disk. It provides memory abstraction.

questions.question: What is a fixed-size block of physical memory?
questions.explanation: Frames are fixed-size blocks of physical memory. Virtual memory pages map to these frames through page tables.

questions.question: What is a fixed-size block of virtual memory?
questions.explanation: Pages are fixed-size units of virtual memory. They're mapped to physical frames and can be swapped to disk when needed.

questions.question: What exception occurs when accessing a page not in memory?
questions.explanation: Page faults trigger when referencing pages not in RAM. The OS handles them by loading the page from disk.

questions.question: What structure translates virtual to physical addresses?
questions.explanation: Page tables map virtual page numbers to physical frame numbers. Each process has its own page table.

questions.question: What occurs when the system spends excessive time paging?
questions.explanation: Thrashing happens when constant page swapping leaves little time for execution. It severely degrades system performance.

questions.question: What memory scheme uses variable-sized logical units?
questions.explanation: Segmentation divides memory into logical units like code, data, and stack. Segments can vary in size.

questions.question: What technique loads pages only when accessed?
questions.explanation: Demand paging defers page loading until access, triggering page faults. It reduces startup time and memory usage.

questions.question: What algorithm replaces the oldest page in memory?
questions.explanation: FIFO replaces the page loaded longest ago. It's simple but doesn't consider page usage patterns.

questions.question: What algorithm replaces the least recently used page?
questions.explanation: LRU replaces pages unused for the longest time. It approximates optimal replacement but is expensive to implement.
